p: Invasive plant species are becoming increasingly common and can threaten biodiversity across the world [ 31]. Apart from being of biological importance – frequently having a negative effect on local plant communities [ 56, 58, 99] – invasive species also provide particular opportunities to study ecological and evolutionary processes [ 39]. Being just a subset of the species-wide gene pool, possibly suffering severe loss of genetic diversity upon the invasion [ 4, 66], they are nonetheless able to thrive in a novel environment and thereby provide useful study systems for responses to rapid environmental changes [ 21, 39].
